fracas-problems.comment: Translation of the FraCaS test suite into Chinese (Mandarin) as spoken in China (officially spoken) by Cuicui Sun, August, 2012.
Q As are Bs == Q As are As who are Bs
In Mandarin, pronouns have no difference between nominative and accusative cases. In these problem sets, nominative case of English is chosen for morpheme mark.

p.script: 一个 意大利人 成为了 世界 最伟大的 男高音歌唱家
p.translit: yi-ge yidaliren chengwei-le shijie zuiweida-de nangaoyin-gechangjia
p.morph: a-CL Italian become-LE[past] world greatest-DE tenor-singer
p.english: An Italian became the world's greatest tenor.

q.script: 有没有 一个 意大利人 成为了 世界 最伟大的 男高音歌唱家？
q.translit: you-mei-you yi-ge yidaliren chengwei-le shijie zuiweida-de nangaoyin-gechangjia
q.morph: there-not-there-be a-CL Italian become-LE[past] world greatest-DE tenor-singer?
q.english: Was there an Italian who became the world's greatest tenor?

h.script: 有个 意大利人 成为了 世界 最伟大的 男高音歌唱家
h.translit: you-ge yidaliren chengwei-le shijie zuiweida-de nangaoyin-gechangjia
h.morph: there-be-CL Italian become-LE[past] world greatest-DE tenor-singer
h.english: There was an Italian who became the world's greatest tenor.

problem.note: 'DE' refers to the connective character between adjective and noun, which is not necessary for all such cases or just assist an adjective in the end. 'CL' refers to classifier particularly preceded by a numeral or determiner or 'there-be'.

p.script: 每个 意大利 男人 都 想 成为 一名 伟大的 男高音歌唱家
p.translit: mei-ge yidali nanren douxiang chengwei yiming weida-de nangaoyin-gechangjia
p.morph: every-CL Italian man all want become a-CL great-DE tenor-singer
p.english: Every Italian man wants to be a great tenor.

p.script: 一些 意大利 人 是 伟大的 男高音歌唱家
p.translit: yixie yidali ren shi weida-de nangaoyin-gechangjia
p.morph: some Italian man are great-DE tenor-singer
p.english: Some Italian men are great tenors.

q.script: 意大利 人 有没有 想 成为 一名 伟大的 男高音歌唱家 的？
q.translit: yidali ren you-mei-you xiang chengwei yi-ming weida-de nangaoyin-gechangjia de?
q.morph: Italian man there-not-there-be want become a-CL great-DE tenor-singer DE?
q.english: Are there Italian men who want to be a great tenor?

h.script: 意大利 人 有 想 成为 一名 伟大的 男高音歌唱家 的
h.translit: yidali ren you xiang chengwei yi-ming weida-de nangaoyin-gechangjia de
h.morph: Italian man there-be want become a-CL great-DE tenor-singer DE
h.english: There are Italian men who want to be a great tenor.

problem.note: Note that second premise is unnecessary and irrelevant. 'DE' in the question acts as a ending character to adjunct the the phrase between itself and 'there-be' or 'there-not-there-be'. In premise2, 'tenor' has no change in numbers, nouns in Chinese always follow this rule.

p.script: 所有 意大利 男人 都想 成为 一名 伟大的 男高音歌唱家
p.translit: suoyou yidali nanren dou xiang chengwei yi-ming weida-de nangaoyin-gechangjia
p.morph: all Italian man all want become a-CL great-DE tenor-singer
p.english: All Italian men want to be a great tenor.

p.script: 一些 意大利 人 是 伟大的 男高音歌唱家
p.translit: yixie yidali ren shi weida-de nangaoyin-gechangjia
p.morph: some Italian man are great-DE tenor-singer
p.english: Some Italian men are great tenors.

p.translit: mei-ge yidali nangaoyin-gechangjia dou xiang shi weida-de

q.translit: yidali nangaoyin-gechangjia you-mei-you xiang biande weida-de?
q.morph: Italian tenor-singer there-not-there-be want become great DE?

h.translit: yidali nangaoyin-gechangjia you xiang biande weida-de

problem.note: Note that second premise is unnecessary and irrelevant.

p.script: 极其 有抱负的 男高音歌唱家 是 意大利人
p.translit: jiqi youbaofu-de nangaoyin-gechangjia shi yidali-ren

q.script: 极其 有抱负的 男高音歌唱家 有没有 意大利人 呢？
q.translit: jiqi youbaofu-de nangaoyin-gechangjia you-mei-you yidali-ren ne?
q.morph: really ambitious-DE tenor-singer there-not-there-be Italian-man NE?
q.english: Are there really ambitious tenors who are Italian?

h.script: 极其 有抱负的 男高音歌唱家 有 意大利人
h.english: There are really ambitious tenors who are Italian.

problem.note: 'NE' in the morph of question is a ending character particularly for question.

p.script: 极其 伟大的 男高音歌唱家 没有 谦逊的
p.translit: jiqi weida-de nangaoyin-gechangjia meiyou qianxun-de
p.morph: really great-DE tenor-singer no modest-DE
p.english: No really great tenors are modest.

q.script: 极其 伟大的 男高音歌唱家 有没有 谦逊的?
q.translit: jiqi weida-de nangaoyin-gechangjia you-mei-you qianxun-de?
q.morph: really great-DE tenor-singer there-not-there-be modest-DE?

h.script: 极其 伟大的 男高音歌唱家 有 谦逊的
h.english: There are really great tenors who are modest.

p.translit: yixie weida-de nangaoyin-gechangjia shi ruidianren
p.morph: some great-DE tenor-singer are Swedish

q.script: 伟大的 男高音歌唱家 有没有 瑞典人 呢？
q.translit: weida-de nangaoyin-gechangjia you-mei-you ruidianren ne?
q.morph: great-DE tenor-singer there-not-there-be Swedish NE?

h.script: 伟大的 男高音歌唱家 有 瑞典人
h.english: There are great tenors who are Swedish.

p.translit: henduo weida-de nangaoyin-gechangjia shi deguoren
p.morph: many great-DE tenor-singer are German
p.english: Many great tenors are German.

q.translit: weida-de nangaoyin-gechangjia you-mei-you deguoren ne?

h.script: 伟大的 男高音歌唱家 有 德国人
h.english: There are great tenors who are German.

p.script: 几个 伟大的 男高音歌唱家 是英国人
p.translit: ji-ge weida-de nangaoyin-gechangjia shi yingguoren
p.morph: several-CL great-DE tenor-singer are British
p.english: Several great tenors are British.

q.script: 伟大的 男高音歌唱家 有没有 英国人 呢？
q.translit: weida-de nangaoyin-gechangjia you-mei-you yingguoren ne?
q.morph: great-DE tenor-singer there-not-there-be British NE?
q.english: Are there great tenors who are British?

h.script: 伟大的 男高音歌唱家 有 英国人
h.english: There are great tenors who are British.

p.translit: duoshu weida-de nangaoyin-gechangjia shi yidaliren
p.morph: most great-DE tenor-singer are Italian
p.english: Most great tenors are Italian.

q.script: 伟大的 男高音歌唱家 有没有 意大利人 呢？
q.translit: weida-de nangaoyin-gechangjia you-mei-you yidaliren ne?
q.morph: great-DE tenor-singer there-not-there-be Italian NE?
q.english: Are there great tenors who are Italian?

h.script: 伟大的 男高音歌唱家 有 意大利人
h.english: There are great tenors who are Italian.

p.script: 很少 有 伟大的 男高音歌唱家 唱 流行 音乐 的
p.translit: henshao you weida-de nangaoyin-gechangjia chang liuxing yinyue de
p.morph: a-few there-be great-DE tenor-singer sing popular music DE
p.english: A few great tenors sing popular music.

p.script: 一些 伟大的 男高音歌唱家 喜欢 流行 音乐
p.translit: yixie weida-de nangaoyin-gechangjia xihuan liuxing yinyue
p.morph: some great-DE tenor-singer like popular music
p.english: Some great tenors like popular music.

q.script: 伟大的 男高音歌唱家 有没有 唱 流行 音乐 的？
q.translit: weida-de nangaoyin-gechangjia you-mei-you chang liuxing yinyue de?
q.morph: great-DE tenor-singer there-not-there-be sing popular music DE?
q.english: Are there great tenors who sing popular music?

h.script: 伟大的 男高音歌唱家 有 唱 流行 音乐 的
h.translit: weida-de nangaoyin-gechangjia you chang liuxing yinyue de
h.morph: great-DE tenor-singer there-be sing popular music DE
h.english: There are great tenors who sing popular music.

problem.note: Note that second premise is unnecessary and irrelevant.

p.script: 伟大的 男高音歌唱家 几乎没有 穷的
p.translit: weida-de nangaoyin-gechangjia jihu-meiyou qiong-de
p.morph: great-DE tenor-singer almost-no poor-DE
p.english: Few great tenors are poor.

q.script: 伟大的 男高音歌唱家 有没有 穷的？
q.translit: weida-de nangaoyin-gechangjia you-mei-you qiong-de?
q.morph: great-DE tenor-singer there-not-there-be poor-DE?
q.english: Are there great tenors who are poor?

h.script: 伟大的 男高音歌唱家 有 穷的
h.english: There are great tenors who are poor.

p.script: 两个 男高音 主唱 都 很出色
p.translit: liang-ge nangaoyin zhu-chang dou hen-chuse
p.morph: two-CL tenor leading-sing all very-excellent
p.english: Both leading tenors are excellent.

p.script: 出色的 男高音 主唱 是 不可或缺的
p.translit: chuse-de nangaoyin zhu-chang shi bukehuoque-de
p.morph: excellent tenor leading-sing are indispensable-DE
p.english: Leading tenors who are excellent are indispensable.

q.script: 两个 男高音 主唱 都 不可或缺 吗？
q.translit: liang-ge nangaoyin zhu-chang dou bukehuoque ma?
q.morph: two-CL tenor leading-sing all indispensable MA?
q.english: Are both leading tenors indispensable?

h.script: 两个 男高音 主唱 都 不可或缺
h.english: Both leading tenors are indispensable.

problem.note: 'MA' in the morph of question is a ending character particularly for question. In the translation of 'both', it is divided into two distant constituents 'two-CL' and 'all'. Also, in the translation, it also could be true if there are three or more leading tenors, so we can't say these two leading tenors are indispensable, it could have a third one who can be in the indispensable group, thus, the answer is 'unknown'.

p.script: 两个 一流的 男高音 主唱 都 身价不菲
p.translit: liang-ge nangaoyin zhu-chang dou shen-jia-bu-fei
p.morph: two-CL tenor leading-sing all body-price-not-cheap
p.english: Neither leading tenor comes cheap.

p.script: 其中一个 男高音 主唱 是 帕瓦罗蒂
p.translit: qizhongyige nangaoyin zhu-chang shi pawaluodi
p.morph: among-one-CL tenor leading-sing is Pavarotti
p.english: One of the leading tenors is Pavarotti.

q.script: 帕瓦罗蒂 是 一位 身价便宜的 男高音 主唱 吗？
q.translit: pawaluodi shi yi-wei shen-jia-pianyi-de nangaoyin zhu-chang ma?
q.morph: Pavarotti is a-CL body-price-cheap-DE tenor leading-sing MA?
q.english: Is Pavarotti a leading tenor who comes cheap?

h.script: 帕瓦罗蒂 是 一位 身价便宜的 男高音 主唱
h.translit: pawaluodi shi yi-wei shen-jia-pianyi-de nangaoyin zhu-chang
h.morph: Pavarotti is a-CL body-price-cheap-DE tenor leading-sing
h.english: Pavarotti is a leading tenor who comes cheap.

problem.note: In the translation of 'neither', it is divided into three distant constituents 'two-CL', 'all' and 'not'( 'not' is sometimes embedded in the other phrase), here, 'not' is found in 'body-price-not-cheap'.

p.script: 至少 三位 男高音歌唱家 会 参加 音乐会
p.translit: zhishao san-wei nangaoyin-gechangjia hui canjia yinyuehui
p.morph: at-least three-CL tenor-singer will take-part-in concert
p.english: At least three tenors will take part in the concert.

q.script: 有没有 男高音歌唱家 会 参加 音乐会？
q.translit: you-mei-you nangaoyin-gechangjia hui canjia yinyuehui?
q.morph: there-not-there-be tenor-singer will take-part-in concert?
q.english: Are there tenors who will take part in the concert?

h.script: 有 男高音歌唱家 会 参加 音乐会
h.english: There are tenors who will take part in the concert.

p.script: 最多 两位 男高音歌唱家 会 向 慈善机构 捐 款
p.translit: zuiduo liang-wei nangaoyin-gechangjia hui xiang cishanjigou juan kuan
p.morph: at-most two-CL tenor-singer will to charity contribute fee
p.english: At most two tenors will contribute their fees to charity.

q.script: 男高音歌唱家 有没有 会 向 慈善机构 捐 款 的？
q.translit: nangaoyin-gechangjia you-mei-you hui xiang cishanjigou juan kuan de?
q.morph: tenor-singer there-not-there-be will to charity contribute fee DE?
q.english: Are there tenors who will contribute their fees to charity?

h.script: 男高音歌唱家 有 会 向 慈善机构 捐 款 的
h.translit: nangaoyin-gechangjia you hui xiang cishanjigou juan kuan de
h.morph: tenor-singer there-be will to charity contribute fee DE
h.english: There are tenors who will contribute their fees to charity.

fracas-problems.comment: Q As are Bs and all Bs are Cs < Q As are Cs

p.script: 一个 爱尔兰人 赢得了 诺贝尔 文学 奖
p.translit: yi-ge aierlanren yingde-le nuobeier wenxue jiang
p.morph: a-CL Irishman win-LE[past] Nobel literature prize
p.english: An Irishman won the Nobel prize for literature.

q.script: 一个 爱尔兰人 赢得了 一个 诺贝尔 奖 吗？
q.translit: yi-ge aierlanren yingde-le yi-ge nuobeier jiang ma?
q.morph: a-CL Irishman win-LE[past] a-CL Nobel prize MA?
q.english: Did an Irishman win a Nobel prize?

h.script: 一个 爱尔兰人 赢得了 一个 诺贝尔 奖
h.translit: yi-ge aierlanren yingde-le yi-ge nuobeier jiang
h.morph: a-CL Irishman win-LE[past] a-CL Nobel prize
h.english: An Irishman won a Nobel prize.

p.script: 每个 欧洲人 都 有权 居住 在 欧洲
p.translit: mei-ge ouzhouren dou you-quan juzhu zai ouzhou
p.morph: every-CL European all have-right live in Europe
p.english: Every European has the right to live in Europe.

p.script: 每个 欧洲人 都 是 一个 人
p.translit: mei-ge ouzhouren dou shi yi-ge ren
p.morph: every-CL European all is a-CL person
p.english: Every European is a person.

p.script: 每个 有权 居住 在 欧洲 的 人 可以 在 欧洲 境内 自由 旅行
p.translit: mei-ge you-quan juzhu zai ouzhou de ren keyi zai ouzhou jingnei ziyou luxing
p.morph: every-Cl have-right live in Europe DE person can in Europe within-boundary freely travel
p.english: Every person who has the right to live in Europe can travel freely within Europe.

q.script: 每个 欧洲人 都 可以 在 欧洲 境内 自由 旅行 吗？

q.morph: every-Cl European all can in Europe within-boundary freely travel MA?

p.script: 成员国 居民 有权 居住 在 欧洲
p.translit: chengyuan-guo jumin you-quan juzhu zai ouzhou
p.morph: member-state resident have-right live in Europe

p.script: 所有 成员国 居民 都 是 个体
p.translit: suoyou chengyuan-guo jumin dou shi geti
p.morph: all member-state resident all are individual
p.english: All residents of member states are individuals.

p.translit: mei-ge you-quan juzhu zai ouzhou de geti dou keyi zai ouzhou jingnei ziyou luxing

problem.why: OK to drop adjunct in positive context
problem.note: In the translation of question, past tense for 'finish' is divided into two distant constituents 'finish' and 'LE'.In the question, 'LE' is mostly placed in the end (before ending character 'MA') to emphasize the tense and the completion of the action.

q.script: 许多 代表 得到 来自 调查 有意思的 结果 了 吗？

q.morph: many delegate obtain from survey interesting-DE result LE[past] MA

h.script: 许多 代表 得到了 来自 调查 有意思的 结果
h.translit: xuduo daibiao dedao-le laizi diaocha youyisi-de jieguo
h.morph: many delegate obtain-LE[past] from survey interesting-DE result
h.english: Many delegates obtained interesting results from the survey.

problem.note: This answer seems dubious to me. Apparently the FraCaS people interpret "many" as denoting a large proportion, whereas I interpret it as denoting a large absolute number. That is, if "many" is regarded as a binary generalized quantifier, they want to say it's non-monotone in the first argument (and upward-monotone in the second), whereas I would say it's upward-monotone in both arguments. Note that this problem is exactly the inverse of problem fracas-72.

problem.note: Note that this problem is exactly the inverse of problem fracas-60. If the answer is "yes", then apparently the FraCaS people interpret "few" as denoting a small absolute number, rather than a small proportion. That is, if "few" is regarded as a binary generalized quantifier, they want to say it's downward-monotone in the first argument, rather than non-monotone. Contrast this with the treatment of "many" in fracas-56 and fracas-72, which is apparently interpreted to be non-monotone in its first argument.

fracas-problems.comment: A number of inferences pertaining to plurals are covered under the headings of generalized quantifiers and elsewhere. Here we concentrate on conjoined NPs; bare, existential and definite plurals; dependent plurals; and collective and distributive readings and scope ambiguity.

fracas-problems.comment: Nbar conjunction tends to be quite ambiguous. This may be the result of a syntactic ambiguity between (i) genuine Nbar conjunction, and (ii) NP conjunction where the determiner of one of the NPs is ellided.

problem.why: Arguably NP conjunction: every representative and every client.
problem.note: 'and' has two translations in Mandarin. One is a conjunction '和' in 'every representative and every client', and the other is noted in problem 088. Here, 'client' must be added determiner 'every' to distinguish in number. Nouns of Mandarin have no inflection in number.

a.translit: bu zhidao, cong yi-zhong lijie shang
a.morph: not know, from one-CL reading on

problem.why: NBar conjunction: everyone who is both a representative and a client.
problem.note: In Mandarin, 'and' could be a verb '兼' to refer to hold two or more jobs or titles concurrently in 'every representative who also "and" a client 'Here, 'every representative' could be a third one who isn't a client.

p.script: 每个 代表 兼(和 每个) 客户 参加了 会议
p.translit: mei-ge daibiao jian(he mei-ge) kehu canjia-le huiyi
p.morph: every-CL representative and (and every-CL) client attend-LE[past] meeting
p.english: Every representative and client was at the meeting.

q.script: 每个 代表 和 每个 客户 参加 会议 了 吗？
q.translit: mei-ge daibiao he mei-ge kehu canjia huiyi le ma?
q.morph: every-CL representative and every-CL client attend meeting LE[past] MA?
q.english: Was every representative and every client at the meeting?

h.script: 每个 代表 和 每个 客户 参加了 会议
h.translit: mei-ge daibiao he mei-ge kehu canjia-le huiyi
h.morph: every-CL representative and every-CL client attend-LE[past] meeting
h.english: Every representative and every client was at the meeting.

problem.why: With disjunction, NP conjunction seems unavailable.

fracas-problems.comment: Definite plurals can often be non-anaphoric and behave like universally quantified noun phrases (90). However, as with (generic) bare plurals, the force of the quantification can also be less than universal (91). Whether this lessening of quantificational force is due to the noun phrase or to the predicate of which the NP is an argument is unclear (92, 93).

fracas-problems.comment: Bare plurals can exhibit existential, (quasi) universal, generic or dependent plural behaviour.
The circumstances giving rise to these different behaviours a poorly understood, so we only give a few illustrative examples.

p.script: 系统 故障 被归咎于 软件 缺陷
p.translit: xitong guzhang bei-guijiu-yu ruanjian quexian
p.morph: system failure BEI[pass]-blame-for software fault
p.english: Software faults were blamed for the system failure.

q.translit: xitong guzhang bei-guijiu-yu yi-ge huozhe duo-ge ruanjian quexian ma?
q.morph: system failure BEI[pass]-blame-for one or more software fault MA?
q.english: Was the system failure blamed on one or more software faults?

h.script: 系统 故障 被归咎于 一个 或者 多个 软件 缺陷

h.morph: system failure BEI[pass]-blame-for one or more software fault
h.english: The system failure was blamed on one or more software faults.

problem.note: Past tense can't be marked in a natural way in this problem whereas it's common to be with an adverbial of time to clear out what the tense is.

p.translit: xitong guzhang bei-guijiu-yu ruanjian quexian

p.english: Software faults were blamed for the system failure.

p.translit: cuowu # 32-985 shi yi-ge yizhi ruanjian quexian

p.english: Bug # 32-985 is a known software fault.

q.script: 系统 故障 被归咎于 错误 # 32-985 吗？
q.translit: xitong guzhang bei-guijiu-yu cuowu# 32-985 ma?
q.morph: system failure BEI[pass]-blame-for # 32-985 MA?
q.english: Was Bug # 32-985 blamed for the system failure?

h.script: 系统 故障 被归咎于 错误 # 32-985
h.english: Bug # 32-985 was blamed for the system failure.

problem.why: Existential interpretation: not every software fault contributed to the failure.

p.script: 系统 性能 演示 给 所有 观摩的 客户 留下了 深刻的 印象
p.translit: xitong xingneng yanshi gei suoyou-guanmo-de kehu liuxia-le shenke-de yinxiang
p.morph: system performance demonstration GEI all-view-DE client leave-LE[past] deep-DE impression
p.english: Clients at the demonstration were all impressed by the system's performance.

p.script: 史密斯 是 一个 观摩演示的 客户
p.translit: shimisi shi yi-ge guanmo-yanshi-de kehu
p.morph: Smith is a-CL view-demonstration-DE client
p.english: Smith was a client at the demonstration.

q.script: 系统 性能 演示 给 史密斯 留下了 深刻的 印象 吗？
q.translit: xitong xingneng yanshi gei shimisi liuxia-le shenke-de yinxiang ma?
q.morph: system performance demonstration GEI all-view-DE client leave-LE[past] deep-DE impression MA?
q.english: Was Smith impressed by the system's performance?

h.script: 系统 性能 演示 给 史密斯 留下了 深刻的 印象
h.translit: xitong xingneng yanshi gei shimisi liuxia-le shenke-de yinxiang
h.morph: system performance demonstration GEI Smith leave-LE[past] deep-DE impression
h.english: Smith was impressed by the system's performance.

problem.note: In the translation of premise1, 'GEI' with 'leave' together corresponds to passive expression. Mandarin doesn't have a reading which correspond to 'He is impressed' whereas the event makes 'him' 'impressed' must exist. So, 'He is impressed by the show' is translated to 'Show GEI him leave deep-DE impression'

fracas-problems.comment: In the examples below we make the assumption (unless otherwise indicated) that there is no context beyond that provided by the mini-discourse. This is so that we can do away with explicit co-indexing of pronouns with their antecedents, on the grounds that context will provide only (or sometimes a strictly limited number) of possible antecedents.

p.script: 玛丽 用了 她的 工作站

p.english: Mary used her workstation.

q.script: 玛丽的 工作站 被用了 吗？
q.translit: mali-de gongzuozhan bei-yong-le ma?
q.morph: Mary-DE workstation BEI[pass]-use-LE[past] MA?
q.english: Was Mary's workstation used?

h.script: 玛丽的 工作站 被用了
h.english: Mary's workstation was used.

problem.note: In the translation of premise, 'she-DE' is possessive pronoun by a suffix 'DE' to 'she', which means, personal pronoun of nominative case plus 'DE' corresponds to a possessive case. In the translation of question and hypothesis, 'BEI' plus an active verb corresponds to a passive case.

h.english: Every committee has a chairman appointed by members of the committee.

problem.note: 'YOU'...'SUO' plus an active verb is another way which corresponds to a passive case. The content between 'YOU' and 'SUO' refers to the carrier on the action.

problem.note: In the translation of premise2, 'DE' is left out for forming a possessive case of 'she'. Keeping it or not depends on different context. Also, 'ZAI' of 'ZAI desk on' could be either a verb in premise2 or a preposition in the question

problem.note: In the translation of premise2,'BA'is a sign to make prepositional object. So,'subject+verb+object' is converted to 'subject BA object verb'.

fracas-problems.comment: Due to the heavy domain dependence of functional (or better perhaps, relational) anaphora, it is hard to state general inferences that don't assume considerable background knowledge unless this is given explicitly.

h.english: Someone said John had been hurt.

fracas-problems.comment:
In nearly all cases the inferences presented here have conclusions that are simply reconstructions of the ellided constituent. Unfortunately, an inference test suite is not well suited to illustrating prohibitions on ellipsis resolution. For example, an ill-formed discourse like
John was in Paris yesterday. *So did Bill.
doesn't even get as far as supporting any inferences.

fracas-problems.comment: Antecedent contained deletion is a notorious problem for copying approaches to ellipsis, since the antecedent clause contains the ellipsis and some way must be found of removing it from the copy.

fracas-problems.comment: Note that the first sentence in (175) and (176) is syntactically ambiguous, depending on whether the conjunctive clause conjoins with the main or subordinate clause of "John said Mary wrote a report". In (177) the conjunctive clause unambiguously conjoins with the subordinate clause, and only one interpretation of the ellipsis is possible. This appears to indicate that the antecedent clause to a VP ellipsis must be adjacent to the elliptical clause. However, as the examples below show, this is not correct.

fracas-problems.comment: Other configurational effects of the kinds illustrated in Deliverable 7 are hard to exemplify using inference suites.
The following inferences illustrate differences between strict and sloppy interpretations of anaphors in elliptical clauses.

fracas-problems.comment: Scope parallelism turns out to be rather tricky to illustrate through inference suites. This is because of the entailment relation: 98 j= 89.

p.translit: yi-ge lushi qian-le mei-yi-fen baogao, yi-ge shenji ye zheme zuo-le

p.english: A lawyer signed every report, and so did an auditor.

p.translit: jiushishuo, you yi-ge lushi, ta（ta） qian-le suoyou-de baogao
p.morph: namely, there-be one-CL lawyer, he(she) sign-LE[past] all-DE report
p.english: That is, there was one lawyer who signed all the reports.

h.morph: there-not-there-be one-CL lawyer, he(she) sign-LE[past] all-DE report
h.english: There was one auditor who signed all the reports.

fracas-problems.comment: The inferences below carve up adjectives into (a by no means exhaustive) cross-cutting set of dimensions. Typical inferences are given for example adjectives.

Affirmative adjectives map the denotation of the predicate they modify onto a subset of the denotation. So for example, an old man is a man. Most adjectives are affirmative, but a few like former and fake are not. Given that someone is a former student, one cannot conclude that they are now a student. But it is not entirely clear whether one can conclude that they are not now a student ... they may have become one again.

p.morph: John have a-CL genuine-diamond

problem.why: Affirmative adjectives: Adj N entails N

q.english: Is John a university student?

problem.why: Non-affirmative: Adj N =/=> N (Opinions differ about whether "Adj N entails !N")

fracas-problems.comment: Gradable adjectives (e.g. big, small) usually assume some form of comparison class (i.e. "big for an N"). But some others do not e.g. four-legged, or the adjectival phrase ten foot long. Adjectives not requiring a comparison class permit straightforward predication without reference to a nominal property providing a comparison class: a ten foot long alligator is ten foot long.

fracas-problems.comment: Large and small (applied to the same comparison class) are opposites. If something is a small N it cannot be a large N, and vice versa. Some things can be neither large nor small Ns.

problem.why: Adjectives requiring a comparison class cannot usually be predicated in the absence of a common noun, unless some comparison class is clear from the wider context.

fracas-problems.comment: Some adjectives require an "intensional" comparison class: different inferences may follow when two distinct but co-extensive predicates provide the comparison class.

fracas-problems.comment: Note that both intensional and extensional comparison class adjectives support comparatives.

Comparison class adjectives can sometimes pick up a default comparison class from the subject NP. For example, knowing that Kim is a person provides a default scale for assessing cleverness in people. If Kim were known to be a dog, the assessment scale would be different.

problem.note: In the translation of premise1, 'DE[cp]' is a connective character between verb/adjective and complement. The complement is generally an adjective or adverb. It is redundant to keep an extra character for past tense which is left out here.

fracas-problems.comment: Inferences (233)-(235) are similar to (230)-(232). Note however, that if "APCOM" can be interpreted as referring to a particular order (e.g. "the APCOM contract"), as it can in (233), the sentence ITEL won more orders than APCOM is ambiguous between a reading like that in (230)-(232), and one where ITEL won more than just the APCOM order ... see (236)

problem.note: In the translation of premise, 'than...' is used to be in a prior position rather than a complement at the end. In this problem, 'than..' is placed either prior to 'has' or just after 'has a'. It is clear from ambiguity. So does problem 245.

fracas-problems.comment: Inference patterns involving temporal reference are complicated by the interplay between tense, aspectual information, lexical semantics, defeasible interpretation principles such as narrative progression, rhetorical relations, a theory of action and causation, world knowledge, interaction between plurality, genericity and temporal/aspectual phenomena etc. Some of the inferences are very basic, some are more involved. The more complex examples give ample illustration of the fact that temporal phenomena are usually discourse phenomena.

fracas-problems.comment: (258) involves the lexical semantics of found.
Non-context dependent indexicals are reasonably straightforward:

p.script: 会议 开始 于 1994年 7月 4日
p.translit: huiyi kaishi yu yijiujiusi-nian qi-yue si-ri
p.morph: conference start on 1994-year 7-month 4-day
p.english: The conference started on July 4th, 1994.

p.script: 持续了 2天
p.translit: chixu-le 2 tian
p.morph: last-LE[past] 2 day
p.english: It lasted 2 days.

q.script: 会议 在 1994年 7月 8日 结束了 吗？

h.english: The conference was over on July 8th, 1994.

fracas-problems.comment: Context dependent indexicals (e.g. today, yesterday) are evaluated with respect to some temporal reference point (e.g. now):

fracas-problems.comment: Ignoring counterfactual readings, 'before' and 'after' have the following transitivity properties: if X, Y and Z are either all state or accomplishment or achievement or activity denoting sentences we have X < Y. Y < Z. X < Z. where < \in {before; after}

X before Y iff Y after X.

fracas-problems.comment: Here the PP "to the shore" provides an end point or conclusion for the activity.

fracas-problems.comment: Also "before", but not "after", can have a counterfactual meaning. Whether this is a distinct sense of "before" is open to debate:

p.script: 史密斯 在 他 发火 之前 离开了 会场
p.translit: shimisi zai ta fahuo zhi-qian likai-le huichang
p.morph: Smith ZAI he lose-temper ZHI-before leave-LE[past] meeting
p.english: Smith left the meeting before he lost his temper.

q.script: 史密斯 发火了 吗？
q.translit: shimisi fahuo-le ma?
q.morph: Smith lose-temper-LE[past] MA?
q.english: Did Smith lose his temper?

h.script: 史密斯 发火了
h.english: Smith lost his temper.

fracas-problems.comment: With "when" things are even more complicated. The problem is that it is often very difficult to tease apart the temporal from the causal dimension of "when", c.f.

p.script: 当 他们 开通了 M25 高速公路， 交通 也 拥挤了
p.translit: dang ta-men kaitong-le M25 gaosugonglu, cheliu ye yongji-le
p.morph: when he-MEN[pl] open-LE[past] M25 motorway, traffic also crowd-LE[past]
p.english: When they opened the M25, traffic increased.

problem.note: Original is degenerate problem; no question or answer given.

fracas-problems.comment: "In" and "for" adverbials can be used as tests for the aspectual class of verb phrases (or sentences).

fracas-problems.comment: Rhetorical relations like narrative progression are defeasible interpretation principles. They depend on a theory of action and causation and general world knowledge (c.f. (309) and (310)).

p.english: If Jones signed the contract, his heart was beating.

problem.note: In the translation of the question, 'RANG' is another form for describing passive case, like 'BEI' and 'SHOU' in the previous problem sets.
